p: The first Zika case in the cohort was identified on January 2, 2016, followed by 12 cases (detected by rRT-PCR and/or the serological algorithm) through the end of February 2016 ( Fig 2). From the beginning of March to mid-June, which corresponds to the dry season and is typically a period of low transmission of Aedes-borne viruses in the study area [ 24], 20 cases were identified. Zika cases were detected in greater numbers starting in mid-June, and the majority of the cases in the epidemic ( n = 516; 92.1%) occurred by the end of September. Twelve cases occurred between October 2016 and February 2017. The overall incidence of Zika in our study population was 14.0 cases per 100 person-years (95% CI: 12.9, 15.2), and the weekly incidence peaked in the last week of July, at 123.5 cases per 100 person-years (95% CI: 100.0, 152.6) ( Table 2). During the same period, a total of 17 symptomatic DENV infections were identified by rRT-PCR and/or virus isolation, including 3 co-infections with ZIKV. All DENV infections were caused by the DENV-2 serotype.
